Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 10:03AM Carola32 wrote: Conservative surgery is much more common in Europe, apparently the statistics show no higher risk of recurrence if associated with radiation.
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 01:01PM Carola32 wrote: Karen & Raincitygirl made very good points. It is so true about the gut feeling, this is a guy/girl you probably will think of everytime you take a shower, so trust and good communication are essential!  Personally, I chose lumpectomy & radiation; couldn't stand the thought of losing my dear little nipple: I've never loved my breast so much as when my surgeon told me that if I didn't do neo-adj chemo they'd have to take it all (A-cup, tumor just behind the nipple which is how I noticed the lump in the first place). Today, one month after surgery I find my breast to be much smaller, but perky as ever! And, it is still my little girlygirl :-) In the beginning I thought 'What's the big deal? They can just chop it off and I'll get new ones'. No idea why I had those thoughts, maybe I was in acute survival mode, but boy am I glad I didn't think like that for long. In France atleast, clinics are really into the mental impact of having a mastectomy, as they are regarding your looks while on chemo. Losing hair, brows, eyelashes and nails is never fun, but they do come back. About the radiation, I'm no fan, but as I won't have any to my axilla, only the breast, I feel it's manageable. I've heard stories, seen pictures of really bad burns, but one day at a time and taking care of my skin should do it, I have been successful in my other treatments, so why should radiation be any worse?  Having different options & making decisions is so hard, but it is a blessing.
Posts.Title: A nearly impossible decision etherize Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 01:11PM Carola32 wrote: Hi! Winterpeg: my numbness DID resolv by itself! I'm so happy about it, no more numbness in either face, scalp, torso or hands :-D  It went away the same week as my first surgery, about a month ago, so I had it for like 4 weeks. Got me really worried there a while.  I haven't really been taking any supplements, a magnesium pill from time to time though and some spirulina, but I rather eat good and clean than taking supplements, atleast when I'm still under treatment. I eat algae (wakame) almost daily, a lot of vitamins in there, it also has detoxifying properties. My acupuncturer told me neuropathy stays longer if the body (i.e the liver) cannot get rid of the toxins (chemo in my case) quick enough. Detoxifying and taking care of my liver is very important for me as I am ER+: don't want any more bad estrogen floating around in my blood!  Apparently it is working!
Posts.Title: Strange sensations. Carola32 Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 10:35AM Carola32 wrote: Hey Ma, yep the walking thing is quite problematic on T. I'm Post-chemo since the end if June, and since only a couple of weeks I feel fully restored: no more pain, sensations of lactic acid running around in the legmuscles nor excess fatigue. B-vitamins are supposed to be very good for neuropathy, check out what RobynS has to say though about too much B6 etc.  Wishing you all the best, Carola
Posts.Title: Strange sensations. Carola32 Carola32

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2011 12:35AM - edited Aug 23, 2011 12:35AM by Carola32 Martah, Of course there must be drugs for the neuropathy; there always is some drug for hot flashes...tingling etc...but those drugs have side effects of their own. An endocrinologist I saw only once wanted to give me pills for my hot flashes: SE's included a nasty, tingling sensation in the whole body for an hour she said, so I didn't take them. With more and more drugs in your system, your poor liver will just be on overdrive, and if a burdened liver chooses to release estradiol and other bad estrogen (provoking excess estrogen and all the niceties that go with it) in the blood due to lack of energy and too much ingested toxins, well the meds wont do any good in the long run.  I would like to avoid this squirrel wheel of meds, meds, meds and believe you me; France is one of the first countries trying to cure SE's with even more medication, it's a pharmaceutical orgy which is very unhealthy and certainly doesn't solve the initial problem for real. I didn't take any special medication to get rid of neuropathy, but detoxed with good food, exercize & the smiles from family, friends and sometimes myself ;-) Wishing everyone who is suffering a speedy recovery!
Posts.Title: Strange sensations. Carola32 Carola32

Posts.Content: Carola32 wrote: It started day before yesterday; I had an MRI and lay with my arms close to my body, had a 'panic button' in my right hand. Afterwards I had this numb sensation in my right pinky, sensation I had before getting diagnosed when I was run down by fatigue. I thought I may have been in a strange position and that my finger just fell asleep (like I almost did). The day after my chin got numb too..and later yesterday evening my whole face went numb! I have no problem moving muscles in fingers and face (otherwise I would have gone seen someone immediately of course), but when I pinch my cheeks I hardly feel anything.. This morning after a good nights sleep I woke up ok. It has come back though, it's like wearing a waxmask, it doesn't hurt but it's not nice at all...I finished 4 x Taxotere last week and 'only' experienced mild numbness and stings in fingers and feet. I can understand if it's neuropathy in fingers I have, but in the face??!! Has anyone experienced the same? I don't think it's stress related, but it kind of freaked me out last night as I know neuropathy can be hard to get rid of...:-o Of course I thought I'd had metal on me (in my wig I have these small clips but I'm quite positive they are in plastic) and that the MRI had done some damage *blushing*.. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Strange sensations. Carola32 Carola32

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 08:28AM Carola32 wrote: Hello there! I never had cataract surgery, but had an accident concerning my right eye in 2006; my cornea was injured and the scar opened up again in 2007. My vision was only blurry when very tired and after long flights (vibrations from the plane and such). Now, post-chemo, my vision is blurry all the time. My ophtalmologist said I don't need glasses as it's due to injuries and chemo.  Maybe this effect will subside; I know I was very sensitive to light until a couple of weeks ago, and my last chemo was late June. My right eye can still shed tears whenever it feels tired. Wishing you the best. /Carola
Posts.Title: eye problems after chemo zenith4289 mumito

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 12:55PM Carola32 wrote: Hello Linda. My cancer clinic gave me an ice cap to wear during chemo sessions. I have very fine Scandinavian hair, although a lot of it, and it actually worked! I'm on FEC100 since Jan 24th and all the oncs told me I'd loose my hair no matter what about 15 days after my first IV. They seemed very pessimistic about it which was quite annoying. The nurses on the other hand were very optimistic, and although I had lost a little on my second date with the red rain, my chemonurse convinced me to put the hell hat on for the second time, so as to delay the baldness even more. It's been over a month since my first session and just now I start looking like a punkrocker if you look closely :-) There are no real 'holes' and my hair falls off very slowly; I know it's just a question of days before I'll start using my wig outside, but it has really been a great help to not lose hair immediately, and more importantly, not losing it while lying in bed agonizing with side effects. I must add that I cut my hair pixiestyle with bangs to my nosetip before chemo, following the nurses advice. Of course this depends on treatment you receive, I get 4xFEC and 4xTaxotere = Hairloss guaranteed!   Another tips is to put an icedbeautymask over your eye for lash and brow protection, it works the same way. It's funny though, and quite nice, 'cause the first hair that I lost was under my arms and the bikiniline! I guess all the waxing throughout the years helped! Know that the first 10 minutes the ice cap is some nasty business, make sure the nurse puts like a thin cottonhat (or bring one yourself)  on your head first, otherwise it's just pure hell, and that she changes the cap every 20-30 minutes.  All my best, Carola.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 03:43PM Carola32 wrote: Jeanie, radiologists see a lot of things, but they cannot see everything unfortunantely. My nipple got retracted and looked grumpy last year, checked it out after three months. I had also felt some kind of pain, and a lump behind the nipple, off and on for some time, thinking it was due to periods. The radiologist (did mammo and echo) said there was a nodule, but I needed a biopsy to see if it was cancerous or not, but that they needed to take it out in any case scenario. Don't worry yourself to cancer and check it out with a biopsy.

Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2011 01:58PM Carola32 wrote: Hello Polyana! I experienced pain in legs and knees during Taxotere (once every three weeks x 4). My onc gave me tramadol mixed with paracetamol for the pain, but sometimes I had a real hard time walking, especially at the end. Hard to climb stairs, standing up even. It came and went, came and went...Maybe, with your oncs approval, go see an acupuncturer, osteopath or just a good masseur to help you get 'loosened up ' again. I found massages (even by myself) helped a lot. Very light yoga and stretching too. Even if it hurts, you know it's 'just' the chemo and nothing wrong with bones/tendons/muscles. But go easy. I had quite a few issues (nothing really serious, but still annoying and painful) with my knees before chemo (hard work in high heels for many years), my onc warned me beforehand that all this pain would be maximised with Taxotere. Indeed. Express your concerns to your onc once again and insist; as a wise person once said, they are scientists and don't really 'see the pain' in it all.  Hoping you'll get relief soon, I wish you a pleasant Friday afternoon. /Carola.
Posts.Title: My knees are not working Polyana Carola32

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 04:03PM Carola32 wrote: Hi! I also thought chemo meant weight loss in the beginning. I started out in January, and will have my last chemo session in three weeks (yay!) So far, I haven't gained a pound, I've maybe lost six. I think it's important what you eat during chemo, as so many factors can make you gain weight; steroids that trick you into thinking you're hungry, days of lying in bed (depending on how you're feeling) nausea that can only be calmed with special foods, not as much workout as before (I've heard and read people on this forum that do actually work out on chemo day, but I guess it's very personal, and depending on which treatment you get). I could hardly eat during FEC because of nausea and when I ate it was mostly noodles and rice (not so good, made me feel heavy and tired), but now I'm on Taxotere (and a lot of steroids) with a sometimes raging appetite. I take every opportunity to move around, even invested in a crosstrainer, cause sometimes I just don't feel like going outside), taking the stairs, doing yoga to destress the organism, including the liver which can get quite angry if you don't take care of it, especially during chemo (like not exercizing at all, not drinking enough, eating too much acid foods...) You can also gain weight because of the water retention from some treatments, but that, I guess, disappears mostly after treatment, my toes look like small sausages, but hey it's all part of the process.. If I could give you some advice, I would drink a lot of water, stay mobile, massage your legs & feet with cream or oils (organic please) to help with circulation and stiffness and bring calm (I learned how to massage myself, it takes some patience but is so beneficial). Since I'm on chemo it's crazy how much I drink, about three litres a day, and my body keeps asking for more :-) Vegetables, lentils, beans and fruit are my friends from now on, and my body seems to really like it. I think the most important thing is to take care of yourself, but eat right, feel good and indulge sometimes. When I had mouth sores with FEC I ate about a ton of sherbet :-)  Bon courage!

Posts.Content: Carola32 wrote: Hello! I'm due to start radiotherapy on the 30th of Sep. after a successful surgery (lumpectomy) where my nodes (five) were all clear. The radiologist wants to set me up for 8 weeks of daily rads (Mon-Fri), onlyto the breast. I've already had chemo (Jan-July). Has anyone else gone through 8 weeks of radiations? Isn't that very long? I saw 5 weeks are standard, and I am 'only' stage 1, grade 2. My young age apparently has something to do with it (diagnosed just before my 30th b-day).  Does anyone know/have links or studies that show by how much radiation minimizes the recurrence risk? Thank you!  /Carola Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 8 weeks of Radiotherapy Carola32 DebConway

Posts.Content: Carola32 wrote: Hello ladies! I was wondering if anyone could please help and give me some advice concerning node dissection. I have had neo-adjuvant chemo for five months and then had lumpectomy & sentinel node biopsy in July. No problems there but unfortunately they found many ITC's in the node, so we opted for a partial node dissection two weeks ago. I have absolutely nothing or noone to compare with, how the armpit should look, what I should feel..What bothers me is that I have the impression of walking around with a smaller balloon stuck in my armpit; when I'm walking I have no idea what to do with my arm! I imagine the armpit will never look the same again, but frankly it is quite swollen. When I palp the area very slightly it doesn't hurt a lot, but enough to hinder me from raising my arm above shoulderheight. My shoulder is ok for now, but the area just feels so incredibly stiff. If I do my stretching the area warms up and it feels better and is movable, but I feel like something wants to break off in my biceps..Also, I've noticed a cordy thing (which is still quite soft to touch thank god). I hope I haven't overdone anything, as I saw exaggerated exercise can cause cording. I'm aware of the patience needed for this kind of intervention, but if anyone would like to share her experience I would be so grateful. Maybe all of this is normal, as I'm only 17 days post surgery? I have a post-op appointment on Monday (final path report! Moment of truth!), but perhaps someone has a few tricks to learn out while I wait for Monday morning...?  I'm taking my temperature just in case by the way. Wishing a very nice weekend to all of us! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 09:21AM Carola32 wrote: Thank you Lago for your response.  Since chemo brain started I've also started to writing my questions down, so very helpful. If there has been an appointment where I haven't had my list, I've always been 'Darn, forgot to ask'..so I know what you mean :-) On my last appointment with my surgeon, he took my list looked at it and started writing/draw answers while he spoke so I would remember them :-D I'm sure I'm overly concerned about swelling, I just have to think about the lumpectomy and its swelling for about two, three weeks to realize it may be way too early to say anything. Hope the doctors can enlighten me further tomorrow. Meanwhile, I try to stay positive & do my exercizes! Thanks again and enjoy your Sunday.
